MissionCommands.Message: Hello, and welcome to the lunar descent and landing lesson!
In this lesson you will learn the major steps needed to perform a powered descent, and then the lunar landing itself.
The descent consists of four phases.
First is the preparation needed for the burn.
Then there is the descent itself, called the Powered Descent.
Once the majority of the velocity is reduced, the approach phase starts. This phase brings the Lunar Module down to about 2000 feet of altitude.
At 2000 feet, the landing phase starts, where the Lunar Module is slowly hovering down to a soft landing, where you control the Lunar Module using Attitude Hold.
It's a long lesson, so let's just get started. Move into the Lunar Module cockpit by pressing F4 or using the View Selector.
The first thing you will need to do is to read the BRIEFING page of the Mission Pad. Press ROGER when ready.
You are currently in orbit around the Moon, in an undocked configuration. Most of the systems are ready and checked out for landing.
We need to request the time of Powered Descent Initiation to start planning our burn. Use the [C]ommunications menu again and select REQUEST PDI.
Open the LUNAR MAP from the Mission Pad. Notice the marks showing the position of the Pe and Ap passings, as well as the green cursor showing PDI.
The blue cursor is the selected landing site. Moving it will alter the internal REFSMMAT for your IMU platform. This requires the ORDEAL to be set to INRTL first.
Let's do this first, verify that the FDAI 1 mode is set to INRTL on the ORDEAL.
If you now move the landing point using the right side arrows on the map view, the FDAI ball will change. We will get back to the landing point soon.
The next thing we will do is to set up the attitude control modes. On the LGC, key V49E.
N22 should now be loaded, showing the desired attitude.
Use V22E to change R2 to +11000, this will set the initial pitch of our burn to 11000 degrees relative to the landing site.
Ensure the other two registers are +00000, namely ROLL and YAW. If not, use V21 or V23 to change them.
Press PRO to copy N22 into N18, and PRO again to execute. End the routine by either pressing PRO until it ends, or use V34E to terminate it.
Set the ROLL switch in the ATTITUDE CONTROL section on Panel 3 to MODE CONT.
Set the PITCH switch to MODE CONT as well.
Then set the YAW switch to MODE CONT.
And finally set the PGNS Control Mode to AUTO. The attitude of the LM is now in the hands of the PGNS.
Let's also configure the DAP.
Key V48E to reconfigure the DAP, then Key V21E to change R1. Following the DAP Setup checklist, set R1 to +22112 and press ENTER. Hit PRO until the routine is complete.
Key V06N33 to see the time of DPS ignition, set by your request for PDI, meaning the start of the descent. Let's look at the format.
What the registers show is time. R1 is hours, R2 is minutes and R3 is seconds. R3 has the following format: 0SSXX, where SS is the seconds (0 to 60) and the XX is the hundreds of a second.
For example, if the time we wish to modify this to be 102 hours, 50 minutes and 18 seconds, set R1 should be +00102, R2 to +00050 and R3 to +01800.
You can use V22E and V23E to change the minutes and seconds if you wish to modify the value. Anyhow, leave this as we wish to use the ignition time communicated by Mission Control.
We can use the map view to see the point of ignition, marked by the green TIG cursor. It should be just ahead of our Pe point.
Next, verify that the ORDEAL FDAI 1 (and optionally 2) is set to INRTL, then go back into the MAP VIEW.
Move the landing point location so that it's about 350 nautical miles downrange (in the direction of flight) from the TIG mark.
The Landing Point is used as the basis for the Landing Point Designator and the Powered Descent Guidance logic.
Use Timescale to about T minus 25 minutes to ignition, using the Mission Timer.
Now we will set up the Powered Descent using Program 63. Key V37E63E.
Program 63 is used to control the attitude and DPS thrust to guide the LM down towards the Lunar surface, and reduce the majority of the velocity and altitude.
The first page of P63 is V06N61. This shows the Time to go in Braking Phase, time from ignition, and distance to the landing site. On this page, you can enter N33 to see and modify TIG as well.
If you entered N33, press KEY REL to get back to the first page of P63 again, so we can monitor the time to ignition.
Ensure the EVENT TIMER is stopped. Then set the EVENT TIMER to 54:00, and that it's counting up.
Timescale to about T minus 8 minutes to burn. We will start the EVENT TIMER when it's exactly 6 minutes left to ignition.
While we wait, check the FDAI. Based on the DAP setting, the FDAI can show a slight error in YAW and ROLL. We will correct this very soon.
At exactly T minus 6 minutes, start the EVENT TIMER!
During P63 and P64, the PGNS will control our attitude.
With the event timer started, key PRO to proceed in P63. You will now see V50N18, meaning that the spacecraft is requesting to maneuver to the burn location. Press PRO again to accept this.
The registers will now show you the desired attitude of ignition. If you need to modify the attitude, you can do this here.
Now, verify that the ROLL ATTITUDE CONTROL mode to MODE CONT
Do the same for YAW as well.
When you accepted the maneuver, the deadband in the DAP was automatically set to 1 degree.
The DAP will try to keep the desired attitude in all axes during the descent, but be prepared to take over if anything happens.
When you are satisfied, verify rates are nulled and that the attitude is good, then press PRO on the LGC. The DSKY displays V06N62.
The most important piece of data is in R2, the time to ignition. R1 shows the absolute value of your velocity and R3 shows the accumulated delta V.
With T minus 2 minutes to ignition, set MASTER ARM to ON.
The DPS engine uses the leftovers of the Ambient Helium tank pressurize the DPS enough for ignition. The ED is then used to trigger an explosion that will enable the SUPER CRITICAL Helium to flow.
The SUPER CRIT He will then pressurize the DPS for the duration of the descent. If the ED is not armed, the DPS will choke.
To let the helium flow to the engine, at least one of the DES He regulators needs to be opened. Set the DES He regulator 1 to OPEN.
At T minus 35 seconds, the DSKY will blank for 5 seconds. At T minus 30 seconds, set the ENG ARM switch on Panel 1 to DES, arming the descent engine.
Also, set PRLNT QTY MON switch on Panel 1 to DES 1, so you can monitor the fuel quantity on the digital indicators on the upper part of Panel 1.
At T minus 5 seconds, V99 will show, asking you for permission to ignite the ENGINE. Press PRO once and wait for ignition.
At ignition, V06N63 is displayed, and the engine is buring at 10% as seen on the ENG THRUST COMMAND indicator on Panel 1. The LGC is measuring and modifying the center of gravity.
The EVENT TIMER is also now counting up from time of ignition, where ignition happened at 00:00.
26 seconds after ignition, the LGC commands the engine to full thrust.
Set the MODE SEL switch on PANEL 1, next to the tape instruments to PGNS. This now shows the rate and altitude based on the state vector and LGC calculations.
Open the MISSION PAD and the POWERED DESCENT CHECKLIST. In the P63 section, you can find a cue card. You can use this card to verify your descent trajectory.
Please note that these values are the ideal value, and your values will most likely differ from this quite a lot, based on many factors. But it's a good indication while I improve the algorithms.
Set the DES ENG CMD OVRD switch to ON.
Set the MASTER ARM switch on the ED to OFF.
Monitor the altitude. Verify that the Landing Antenna switch has been set to AUTO, or DESCENT. It's located on the upper left part of Panel 3, named LDG ANT. This tilts the landing radar.
When the altitude reaches about 40k feet, the ALT and VEL warning lights on the LGC should extinguish. This means that the Landing Radar has locked on to the surface.

When this happens, set the MODE SEL switch on panel 1, next to the tape indicators, to LDG RADAR, and see the data on the tapes. This data might show rapid changes due to slopes and mountains on the lunar surface.
Then key V57E on the LGC to let the LGC permit the landing radar data. The LGC shows the differences in altitude, and it's normal that the delta can be in the thousands of feet.
R1 shows the delta altitude, R2 shows the altitude rate, and R3 shows the computed altitude.
As P63 is working, keep monitoring the descent with the cue cards. At the same time, I will brief you on P64 and P66, as during that time, things will be very hectic.
When P64 starts, the LMP will start to periodically let you know of the Landing Point Designator angle, the rate of descent, the altitude and amount of fuel.
During this time, the LM will pitch over and you should be able to see the ground and the landing site (depending on the validity of your selected landing point).
At this time, you need to align the marks on the window so they overlap and turn yellow (green + red = yellow). You can use the F9 view to align the camera too.
During P64, the computer will keep telling you the altitude, along with the tape instruments, as well as the LPD angle.
If the LPD is 35 degrees, the landing site is located on the 35 degree mark on the CDRs window. Don't worry yet on ladning exactly on the mark. We will manuver manually in P66.
When then P64 pitchover starts, you need to set the LDG ANT to HOVER, or leave it in AUTO.
P64 will then try to slow down the rate of descent to better maintain control during the transition from P64 to P66.

At this point, a procedural algorithm will generate a high resolution landscape based on real lunar elevation data and P66 will start. The initial job for P66 is to stabilize the lunar module with 0 zero rate of descent.
Using the attitude hold mode, the lunar module is pitched so it's level with the horizon. When you have control over the spacecraft, look at the X-Pointer indicator.
This indicator shows your velocity components relative to the +Z axis of the Lunar Module.
P66 also has another system, namely the Rate of Descent (ROD) control. There is a switch next to the CDRs TTCA that controls the rate of descent. Initially, this should be around 0.
You can click this switch up to command the rate of descent in the positive direction, or click it down to command the rate of descent downwards. One click equals to about 1 feet pr. second.
You now fly the Lunar Module as a helicopter. Tilt forward to increase forward velocity, and sideways to move left or right. Use steady movements, and keep full focus on attitude control.
When you are satisifed with a landing point, slowly use the ROD control to bring the spacecraft down to a soft landing.
When you touch down, a blue contact light shows. Immediately shut off the engine by pressing the ENG STOP button on the right side of the engine control panel.
After touchdown, we will start P68, the landing confirmation program.
This was a lot of information, but you will be multitasking a lot during these final moments.
During P64, it's also possible to move the landing point using axis mapped for this in INPUT SETTINGS.
Let's wait for P64 to start. Monitor the descent.
P64 has started and the pitchover should happen! Key V77E to prepare the attitude hold mode for P66.

Take a look out the windows and located the landing site. Does it look good? If not, move it SLIGHTLY. If the control mode is set to PGNS, you can use the pitch and roll joystick to move it. If the angle is over 90, it's behind you.
Now monitor the descent rate using the P64 cue card located in the same checklist, and pay attention to the LPD.

P66 will automatically start when P64 is satisfied. During P66, you will have semi-manual control, and will need to land the spacecraft on a flat area, with no boulders. This maneuvering is up to you.
P66! I have set the PGNS mode control to ATT HOLD. You can now use the attitude controls to change attitude. It is configured to rate command attitude hold.

The first thing you need to focus on is the attitude control. Try to level the spacecraft in all axes, and ensure the rate of descent moves towards 0, and note your velocity by looking at the X-pointer and out the windows.

When you have the attitude under control, monitor the altitude, rate of descent, and attitude. While doing this, use the Des Rate clicker switch on Panel 5 to control the rate of descent. Click it once DOWN now.
Notice the rate of descent changed. You can use the ROD key mapping to control this. By default, [T] will decrease the rate of descent, and [G] will increase it.

If you now tilt the Lunar Module forward, your forward speed will increrase. This also tilts the engine a bit and your rate of descent will increase. The LGC detects this, and will try to increase the engine CMD to compensate.
However, anything can happen so keep close attention to your instruments.
When you find a suitable spot, tilt the spacecraft so your velocities on the X-Pointer is nulled, and slowly bring the spacecraft down for a soft landing.

Please note your fuel consuption while doing this. If you are out of fuel, the DPS engine will cut off. When the blue contact lights illuminate, shut down the engine immediately useing the STOP button.
Contact! Shut off the DPS ENGINE immediately!
Now, Key V37E68E to start Program 68. This shows you the landing location and altitude.
Keep practicing on this maneuver, it will become easier and easier for each time you do it. That's it for now.

Title: Lesson 10 - Powered Descent
Description: This lesson will walk you through the steps needed to perform a powered descent and a lunar landing. It's a very advanced lesson and will most likely require some retries.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Powered descent and the lunar landing requires a lot of practice to master.

A powered lunar landing consists of 4 phases.
- Phase 1: Preparation for powered descent
- Phase 2: Powered descent
- Phase 3: Approach
- Phase 4: Landing

Each of these phases has dedicated checklists, all found in the Powered Descent checklist in your Mission Pad.

This lesson will follow the major steps in these checklists, however, with some modifications for simplicity and clarity.

PHASE II: POWERED DESCENT
This phase is the major workhorse for the descent, and has the main objective of reducing the orbital speed, and the majority of the altitude.
The LGC Program 63 is controlling this.

PHASE III: APPROACH
This phase is where the landing point should be visible by the usage of the Landing Point Designator marks on the CDR's window. The landing point can be moved using the attitude control stick (pitch/roll). Keep this to a minimal.
The descent velocity/rate is nulled, and the Lunar Module is brought down to an altitude down to about 2000ft.
The LGC Program 64 is controlling this.
Note: A new guidance logic is controlling your attitude, and is currently in an experimental phase. It's on by default, and you can use V84E to toggle it. If this is off, then the LM will not adjust it's YAW or ROLL during P64.

PHASE IV: LANDING
In this phase, program 66 controls the descent rate of the Lunar Module. In addition, the X-Pointer is used to see the velocity components relative to the Lunar Module +Z axis.
The best method to control your velocity using the X-pointer is to ensure you are in level flight, then yaw until the only velocity component is the forward velocity and tilt slightly backwards to you reduce your forward velocity.
The Rate of Descent switch next to the TTCA controller is used to reduce or increase the rate of descent with about one ft./sec. Default bindings to increase or decrease this is [T] and [G].
When the Lunar Module has contact with the surface, you need to quickly shut off the engine using the STOP button on Panel 5 or Panel 6.

POST LANDING
When you have touched down and settled, run P68. This is the landing-confirmation program.
